bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Chaofeng Hou is an assistant professor at the IPE, CAS. He received his BS from the Department of Chemical Engineering of Xiangtan University in 2003, and obtained his PhD from the IPE, CAS, in Beijing in 2009. Currently, his research area is focused on high-performance computing of solid functional materials and their applications, mechanism research of silane pyrolysis and silicon deposition, and the multi-scale modeling and design of novel silicon-based solar cells and nano/micro systems.

Ji Xu is working for his doctoral degree in Chemical Engineering at the IPE, CAS. He received his bachelor’s degree in Chemical Engineering from the School of Energy and Power Engineering of Xi’an Jiaotong University in 2006. His research interests cover MD simulation of materials and biomolecular systems, such as polyethylene, lipids, and proteins, computer modeling of supramolecular assembly, such as virus capsids, and algorithm design for GPU-based accelerated MD simulations and parallel computing on CPU and GPU hybrid supercomputers.

Peng Wang is the manager of the HPC developer technology in Nvidia, where he works on GPU computing technologies. From 2009 to 2010 he was a senior engineer in the HPC developer technology group, working on computer-assisted engineering solvers and MD. In 2009, he received his PhD in Computational Physics from Stanford University, where he worked on developing multi-physics computational fluid codes and simulating astrophysical turbulences. He also received his MS in Physics in 2005 and his BS in Scientific Computing in 2002 from Nankai University.

Wenlai Huang received his BE degree in materials science from Yanshan University in 1993. In 2001, he received his ME and PhD degrees in materials science from Tsinghua University simultaneously. Since May 2001 he has been a member of the IPE, CAS. During October 2009 to April 2010 he visited the University of Cambridge under the support of the China Scholarship Council. His research now mainly covers first-principles calculations and simulations, aiming at both materials and processes. To date he is the (co-)author of more than 40 articles (cited more than 150 times by others), several conference reports, two books, the inventor or co-inventor of more than 10 patents, the draftsman of two China standards, and the reviewer of many periodicals, including the Journal of Physical Chemistry, Journal of Nanomaterials, Journal of Molecular Structure, Journal of Non-Crystalline Solids, and Journal of Colloid and Interface Science.

Xiaowei Wang is an associate professor at IPE, CAS. He obtained his master’s degree at the University of Petroleum (Beijing), and his PhD degree at IPE, CAS in 2005. From 2006 to 2008, he pursued his postdoctoral research at Nagoya Institute of Technology in Japan, performing molecular modeling to study the formation mechanism using the Bubble Template Method (BTM). His current interest is focused on high-performance computing application in computational chemistry, computational fluid dynamics, and discrete simulation with particle methods. He works on the general platform for large-scale parallel computation based on particle methods, which includes MD, the Pseudo-particle Method (PPM), Dissipative Particle Dynamics (DPD), Smooth Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH), Discrete Element Method (DEM), and Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM). He has published more than 10 research papers in international journals.

Wei Ge is a professor at the IPE, CAS. He got his PhD degree from Harbin Institute of Technology in 1998. As project leader, he developed the Mole series supercomputing systems with an application-oriented design to keep the consistency among the simulated physics, the mathematical model, the numerical algorithm, and computing hardware. The systems have found applications from molecular design to reactor scaling-up, and are aiming at real-time simulation of complex processes in chemical engineering. His research is focused on multi-scale simulation of complex multi-phase systems in process engineering and application of high-performance computing in this area.

Xianfeng He is an associate professor at the IPE, CAS. He received his BS and MS in Chemical Engineering from the Department of Chemical Engineering of Beijing University of Chemical Technology in 1991 and 1996, and a PhD in Chemical Technology from the IPE, CAS. His research field covers high-performance parallel computing, process simulation, molecular simulation, and cheminformatics. He has developed a genetic algorithm named DGA, a computer-aided molecular design system, CASAC, and a rapid sampling and analysis software named SampView.

Li Guo is a professor at the IPE, CAS. He received his BS from the School of Computer Science and Technology of University of Science and Technology of China in 1986, and a MS from the IPE, CAS. His research fields include high-performance computing and cheminformatics.

Jinghai Li is the group leader of complex system and multi-scale methodology at the IPE, CAS. He proposed the multi-scale approach based on the micro scale of individual particles, meso scale of particle aggregates, and macro scale of apparatus, and he formulated the variational criteria for the heterogeneous flow structure of particle-fluid systems that led to the EMMS model. The EMMS approach has been extended to many different complex systems to solve engineering problems and recognized as a way to define a new paradigm of multi-scale computation. He holds bachelor’s and master’s degrees in power engineering from Harbin Institute of Technology and a PhD in chemical engineering from the IPE, CAS.

abstract.p: An efficient and highly scalable bond-order potential code has been developed for the molecular dynamics simulation of bulk silicon, reaching 1.87 Pflops (floating point operations per second) in single precision on 7168 graphic processing units (GPUs) of the Tianhe-1A system. Furthermore, by coupling GPUs and central processing units, we also simulated surface reconstruction of crystalline silicon at the sub-millimeter scale with more than 110 billion atoms, reaching 1.17 Pflops in single precision plus 92.1 Tflops in double precision on the entire Tianhe-1A system. Such simulations can provide unprecedented insight into a variety of microscopic behaviors or structures, such as doping, defects, grain boundaries, and surface reactions.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Crystalline silicon is possibly one of the most important materials for the information technology and solar energy industries. To understand its bulk properties and surface morphology for best quality, high-performance computation (HPC) is in great demand for simulating the formidable number of atoms involved. In particular, simulation of one-dimensional crystalline silicon structures is not only meaningful to understanding of its physical properties, but also to its potential applications in new materials, such as nanowires (Li et al., 2003; Boukai et al., 2008; Heron et al., 2009; Shi et al., 2009; Tian et al., 2009; Donadio and Galli, 2010; Yang et al., 2010a; Yang et al., 2010b). Nanowires are usually defined as strings within tens of nanometers in diameter, and their lengths have reached the millimeter range in experiments (Korgel, 2009; Chan et al., 2010; Heitsch et al., 2011). Their applications include field-effect transistors, photovoltaic and thermoelectric devices, biological and chemical sensors, etc., owing to their unique electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties, and solution dispersibility. In a sense, they are a key player in the future technology of integrated circuit chips and solar cells (Li et al., 2003; Boukai et al., 2008; Heron et al., 2009; Korgel, 2009; Shi et al., 2009; Tian et al., 2009; Chan et al., 2010; Donadio and Galli, 2010; Yang et al., 2010a; Heitsch et al., 2011).

In these materials, dopants or defects, although necessary or unavoidable, are normally of quite low concentrations. In order to have a deep insight into the collective effects of these dopants or defects on thermal properties, such as phonon transport, and mechanical performance, such as the crack generation and propagation, a large size of supercells seems necessary to simulate their behaviors. For instance, the dopant concentration in p- or n-type silicon can be as low as 1015 cm−3, that is, only one dopant atom within (100 nm)3 (Green, 1982; Hu and White, 1983). If we intend to mimic such a system directly, the supercell should be at the micrometric level at least to achieve statistical understandings.

To avoid the finite size effects, a large size scale seems indispensable when thermal transport properties are to be determined through non-equilibrium molecular dynamics (MD) simulations. If we establish a 10 K temperature difference (near the lower limit in MD for thermal fluctuations) over 25 nm (the normal size in MD), the temperature gradient will reach an unrealistic value of 4×108 K/m, violating the linear response theory (Volz and Chen, 2000; Schelling et al., 2002; Tang, 2004; Pascual-Gutierrez et al., 2007; Ponomareva et al., 2007; Donadio and Galli, 2009; Wang et al., 2009; Yang et al., 2010a). Therefore, a much larger size seems important to reduce the gradient to a realistic range.

We developed an algorithm for a central processing unit–graphic processing unit (CPU-GPU) hybrid HPC system to cope with such huge computational cost. The capability of the algorithm was demonstrated by carrying out a MD simulation using more than 110 billion atoms on the whole Tianhe-1A system (the world’s fastest computer before May 2011, and the second fastest now) in April 2011, reaching 1.87 Pflops for the bulk material and 1.17 Pflops in single precision (SP), plus 92.1 Tflops in double precision (DP) when the surface is evolved. Although high-performance MD simulations on fluid flow (Glosli et al., 2007), materials (Germann and Kadau, 2008; Germann et al., 2009), and biochemistry (Narumi et al., 2006; Shaw et al., 2009; Rahimian et al., 2010) have been reported, their sustainable performance has not broken the Petaflops barrier before. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this was the first Petascale MD application, with its nearest rival from Roadrunner reaching 369 Tflops in DP (Germann et al., 2009). The simulation is detailed below and the preliminary results are analyzed.

sec.title: 2. Physical modeling
sec.p:
Reasonable simplification of the physical models can reduce the computational cost to an affordable range and also help the development of efficient algorithms. Without losing generality, our simulation is targeted on a narrow strip with a typical longitudinal length of roughly 1 mm and two lateral lengths of tens of nanometers. Such scales are obviously beyond the first-principles approaches, although they can offer more reliable results. To address the problem with classical MD simulations, certain potentials are needed to describe the interatomic interactions as accurately as possible. Therefore, the Tersoff family bond-order potential (BOP) models (Tersoff, 1986, 1988a, 1988b, 1989), which are among the most successful models for tetravalent atoms, are used in this study. Taking into account the heat and stress changes of crystalline silicon, we employed the Tersoff II potential (Tersoff, 1988a) in the simulation of bulk silicon, which takes the form of

The model parameters used in the above two equations can be seen in Tersoff (1988b) and Ohira et al. (2000), and the main parameters of the maximum simulated systems are listed in Table 1. The surface strip extends along the x-axis. Si(010) is defined as the normal surface, the most popular and thoroughly investigated one, and the atoms of two layers in the bottom in this direction are fixed. In addition, periodic boundary conditions are applied in the x–z plane. We describe the system size as a product (dx × dy × dz ) along these directions. The reduced values favored by numerical treatment are obtained by taking nanometer, atomic mass unit, and picosecond as units of length, mass, and time, respectively. The mass and diameter of silicon atom are 28 and 0.235 in the simulations, respectively. The time step was chosen to be 0.1–1.0 fs.

sec.p: To our knowledge, this is the largest size scale for the MD simulation of crystalline silicon so far. A previous MD simulation for bulk silicon handled ∼109 atoms using another many-body potential (Shimojo et al., 2000). Some investigations on the heat conduction or mechanics of crystalline silicon have reached large sizes on the order of hundreds of nanometers in one dimension (Aubry et al., 2008).

In fact, the physical models thus described are of general significance for many other physical processes, such as the deposition of diamond films, growth of nanostructures of silicon or carbon, etc. The algorithms introduced in the following also respect this generality and provide a basis for these further applications.

sec.title: 3. Simulation methods
sec.p: Programming BOP models on GPUs is more challenging than simple pair potentials, as the branching and data dependence complicates the optimization of instruction flow and memory management (Chen et al., 2009; Hou and Ge, 2012a). In terms of the crystal surface computed by the CPU, where the reconstruction occurs, keeping reasonable computational efficiency and load balancing between different running processes is barely surmountable but is critical to the overall performance of the simulation. To take full advantage of the CPU-GPU hybrid architecture of the recent high-end supercomputers, we try to solve the problems in a systematic way from all aspects of physical models, numerical methods, and algorithms, as well as computer hardware.

Characteristics of the system, a regular crystal lattice in the background, dotted by irregular locations of dopants, defects, boundaries, and surfaces, are presented by a MD model with a fixed neighborhood, for an overwhelming majority of the regular atoms, and a classical dynamic neighborhood for the rest. As shown in Figure 2, under this mode, the precision, data size, and computational load of the respective algorithms for the regular and irregular atoms are best fit into the CPU-GPU heterogeneous architecture of the hardware, making full use of its advantages and avoiding its drawbacks, while serving the solution of the problem with efficiency and accuracy.

caption.p: Annotation of full employment of central processing unit–graphic processing unit (CPU-GPU) hybrid architecture.

sec.p: Our algorithms were implemented on Tianhe-1A (Top500, 2010), which has 7168 computing nodes, each configured with one Tesla M2050 GPU and two Intel hexa-core X5670 CPUs. Each node has 24 GB DDR3 RAM at 1333 Hz. All the computing nodes are linked with 160 Gbit Galaxy Interconnect, which is twice as fast as the QDR Infiniband. Nvidia CUDA 3.0 and Intel C++ compiler 11.1 are used for compiling.

sec.title: 3.1 The GPU algorithm for bulk silicon
sec.p: Due to the limited temperature range in most applications, the crystalline structure of silicon in the bulk is relatively stable, with four direct neighbors that are not likely to change during the process. This feature allows us to bypass the time-consuming and inefficient process of neighbor indexing in traditional MD simulations. However, programming for this Tersoff model is by no means trivial, especially on GPUs. For this many-body potential, computing the interaction with one neighboring atom necessarily involves all other neighbors, which results in frequent memory access. In addition, as each thread launched on the GPU processes only one atom simultaneously, writing the forces exerted on other neighbors directly may cause write conflicts (Hou and Ge, 2012a).

Herein, the algorithm directly builds the mapping between atoms in the simulation system and threads on the GPU via the indices of blocks and threads. Firstly, the atoms in the system are put into the array allocated on device memory sequentially in the order of their indices. Then a certain amount of atoms are assigned to a thread block. If m thread blocks complete the assignment of all N atom atoms in the system, one block contains N atom/m threads on average in the end, which corresponds to processing N atom/m atoms arranged sequentially (see Figure 3). Thus, the correspondence between atoms and threads in the blocks is established, and all atoms in the system can be calculated by the corresponding threads. Note that no idle threads are usually left in the blocks due to the atom number of the system N atom = m*N b (Chen et al., 2009; Hou and Ge, 2012a).

caption.p: Mapping of the threads in the blocks to the calculated atoms when implementing the related kernel functions. N b represents the number of the atoms in each block.

sec.p: Optimally, to minimize global memory (GM) access and avoid write conflicts, buffers for those computed atomic positions and forces are created in the shared memory (SM) of the GPUs, with much faster access. However, the size of SM is very limited, only 48 kB for one multiprocessor of Nvidia M2050. Therefore, efficient use of SM becomes critical. For this propose, we process the atoms in the form of “supercells” corresponding to blocks, each with a number of unit cells of the crystal (see Figure 1) in each direction. The size and aspect ratios of the “supercells” are selected to maximize the number of the atoms, whose neighbors all lie in the “supercell”. In the cases we studied here, the optimal “supercell” has 2×4×4 unit cells in the X, Y, and Z directions, respectively. The atoms in the “supercell” are divided into three groups (see Figure 4). The atoms belonging to the first group have one neighbor inside the “supercell”, the second group with two neighbors inside the “supercell”, and the third group with four neighbors inside. The atoms with the same number of neighbors inside the “supercell” are processed together to reduce branching and ensure coalesced memory access (for details, see Hou et al., 2011).

caption.p: Sorting of the calculated atoms in the “supercell”. The red, green, and blue atoms belong to the first, second, and third groups, respectively (color online only).

sec.p: In addition, the force computation in the algorithm includes two steps in two separate kernels.

Step 1. Collision
By differentiating the potential function, the forces on each atom exerted by its adjacent atoms are calculated by its corresponding thread in the blocks; meanwhile, the inverse forces the four adjacent atoms experienced are written to the force buffers created in SM, or to the force list in GM for the atoms with some of their neighbors outside the “supercell”. It should be noted that the complete resultant forces acting on the atoms in the third group can be obtained in this step, and the positions and velocities of the atoms can be updated.
Step 2. Updating
The forces saved in GM in Step 1 are read back and added to the current atom processed by the corresponding thread, where the saved forces are exerted on the atoms in the first and second groups in each “supercell”. Finally, the resultant force of the atoms in the two groups is obtained, and the positions and velocities of the atoms are updated.
Most of the GPU time is spent in these two kernels, so fine performance tuning is required. According to the instruction-to-byte ratio reported by the Compute Unified Device Architecture (CUDA) visual profiler and manual test, they are neither compute-bound nor memory-bound, and need to be tuned for both. On memory optimization, reduction of GM access is always important, as the M2050 GPUs always load a full L1 cache line (128 B) regardless of how many bytes are actually needed. In this case, the atom position array was bound to the texture memory for which all loads will be cached in the on-chip texture cache. This has the benefits of both reducing redundant GM access when there is a texture cache hit and reducing the wasted GM bandwidth, as the texture transaction size is 32 B. Finally, we want to ensure that there are enough warps on every multiprocessor to hide GM latency as best as possible. Thus, we have performed extensive experiments to choose the best balance between various resources (registers, SM, and block size). On instruction throughput optimization, native GPU math functions are used for all the transcendental functions and floating point divide, which was found to give a tiny difference in comparison to the more precise but more expensive versions.

The parallelization of this algorithm is straight forward, with space decomposition and message-passing interface (MPI) communication. Taking advantage of the fixed neighbor list, the packing and unpacking of the transferred data becomes much simpler, which helps to preserve a low communication overhead (Hou and Ge, 2012b).

sec.title: 3.2 The algorithm for surface reconstruction
sec.p: As described earlier, the surface of the silicon material is processed by CPUs, where the dynamic deformation occurs frequently in response to surface reconstruction. In this situation, a general MD algorithm with a neighbor list updating is employed. The decomposition of the simulation domains is illustrated in Figure 5.

caption.p: Schematic diagram for the decomposition of the simulation domain with surface reconstruction.

sec.p: Although this algorithm is demonstrated in a simple case of one-dimensional structure and with a basically flat surface, it remains effective for more complicated problems with random distribution or non-uniform distribution of the regular atoms with a fixed neighborhood. In that case, the CPU will take care of discontinuous patches in the simulation domain, sending back and forth the data of interfacial atoms to GPUs.

For the current case, the detailed assignment of workload in the algorithm is illustrated in Figure 6. Three regions, A, B, and C, are the coupling regions used commonly by the GPU and CPU. Region A refers to the green rectangle plus its adjacent little gray rectangle, and so forth for regions B, C, and D. The whole gray column is the buffer region on each computing node, where the received data from neighboring nodes are put down. The area between the upright dashed line and the boundary line of the gray region contains the data to be exchanged, which will be sent to neighboring nodes at each time step. After accomplishing the data communication, on a single node, the atoms distributed to the GPU are firstly calculated, then the atomic data corresponding to regions A and B are copied onto the CPU, and the interactive forces between all the atoms in the top regions C and D are processed by the CPU, as displayed in Figure 6. Then, the atomic data corresponding to region C are copied back to the GPU from the CPU in order to keep the regularity of the GPU computing. The patched area (Region C) can be treated by GPUs without discrimination to the down regular areas, but the computational result is disregarded. This redundancy will have little effect on efficiency, considering the very low density of the patches. Region D represents the atomic layers on the surface of crystalline silicon, which are processed only by the CPU.

caption.p: Assignment of the workload among the central processing unit (CPU) and graphic processing unit (GPU) in the coupled algorithm (color online only).

sec.p: In addition, in the inner loop of the force and potential calculation on the CPU, whether the first two atoms are bonded should be detected first, and then the interaction among the three atoms is computed and written back. Considering the speed difference between the CPU and GPU, CPUs are assigned to a minimal number of atoms, and the multi-thread technique is applied here; the multi-thread technique is suitable for the hardware configuration in Tianhe-1A, which has one GPU and twelve CPU cores. However, load balancing among the multiple threads has not been carried out currently, which may result in apparent performance degrading.

sec.title: 4.1 The performance of the algorithm for bulk silicon
sec.p: This algorithm is the main contributor of flops in the program, and is analyzed in the stand-alone mode first. Weak scaling for this algorithm is ideal until the full system scale on Tianhe-1A. Strong scaling is expected to be good also for decreasing the atom number down to 1.64 million per node, as shown in Figure 7, although a rigorous test has not been conducted yet. A sustainable performance of 1.87 Pflops in SP is achieved with 15.36 million atoms per GPU and 110.1 billion in total. This is, to our knowledge, the highest performance of MD simulation reported so far; perhaps the closest work is from Roadrunner (Germann et al., 2009), which reached 369 Tflops in DP. A periodic boundary can be applied when the algorithm is used alone on the GPU, which may still play a role in measuring the bulk properties of the material and their finite size effects.

caption.p: Performance of the simulations of bulk silicon with different node numbers.

sec.p: It can be seen in Figure 8 that the main contribution to the flops is from the interactions among the atoms, while the updating of atomic states costs considerable time but, in fact, it contributes far fewer flops. The communication overhead is reasonably low and has not changed much with increasing node numbers and fewer atoms on each node. The effective memory throughput in these simulations is about 102 GB/s (81% of the peak) and the instruction throughput is around 412 Ginstr/s (80% of the peak). The flops data on GPUs are measured by disassembly of the CUDA code.

caption.p: Breakdown of the computing time for different phases of the simulations of bulk silicon.

sec.title: 4.2 The performance of the coupled algorithm
sec.p: The coupled algorithm involving the GPU and CPU already gives a good tool for testing the material with complicated shapes and deformations, which can find applications in exciting areas, such as silicon nanowire and so forth (Heron et al., 2009). The evaluations found that a good balance between CPU and GPU computing can be achieved and the data communication between the CPU and GPU is mostly overlapped with computation. However, the data communication between the CPUs and the load balancing among the multi-threads are found to be harmful to the overall performance, especially at the first stage of weak scaling. The final sustainable performance on the whole system is now 1.17 Pflops in SP plus 92.1 Tflops in DP (see Figure 9), which is, to our knowledge, one of the highest performances of any kind of MD simulation so far.

caption.p: Performance of the coupled algorithm for different node numbers.

sec.title: 4.3 Preliminary results
sec.p: We examine the details of a small-size simulated system to get a first evaluation of the computational programs and check the effectiveness and correctness of the developed algorithms. In this case, the simulation system is calculated in parallel by four GPUs, with 64,000 atoms per GPU. Periodic boundary conditions are applied in three spatial directions, and the system temperature is assigned at 300 K initially. Examining the simulation results of the microcanonical ensemble, it can be found that the crystal structure in the system is still basically diamond-like when reaching the thermodynamic equilibrium. Observed from the fluctuation of the mean potential energy per atom shown in Figure 10, the statistical result is correct and effective, which is in good agreement with the literature (Tersoff, 1988a, 1988b, 1989).

caption.p: Temporal variation of mean potential energy per atom.

sec.p: For the simulation of larger systems, the effects of numerical precision will become more conspicuous. A variety of cases with different simulation sizes have been conducted to further examine the programs, where each node processes 15,360,000 atoms, and other simulation conditions are similar to the above case with a small size. Since all the simulated cases are microcanonical ensembles, the total system energy should be conserved in the cases. Actually, the total system energy is frequently employed to check and assess the precision of a MD simulation software. Here, the mean total energies per atom computed on a single GPU, 60 GPUs, and 600 GPUs are provided and compared in Figure 11. It can be seen that the computed mean potential energies corresponding to the three situations increase extremely slowly with the simulation time, and the deviation is below 0.02% in 3E5 time steps. Due to the addition of the deviation of mean kinetic energy, the deviation of the mean total energy per atom is about 0.05%, which is larger than that of mean potential energy per atom. Nevertheless, the results indicate that the numerical precision effects are reasonably acceptable with respect to large-scale computation in the simulations (Friedrichs et al., 2009; Bauer et al., 2011).

caption.p: Effects of different computational sizes on the statistical results. The top fitted line represents mean total energy per atom, while the lower one represents mean potential energy per atom. The inset provides the magnification of the top line during its initial stage.

sec.p: The whole program in its full capacity was put into the test running for validation and evaluation. The time of our surface simulation with 111.2 billion atoms is 0.3 ns, which is adequate for the reconstruction process. Seen from the local details on a single node, the captured snapshots obviously reproduced the reconstruction pattern of 2×1 with dimerization on the flat Si(010) surface (see Figure 12), which is the well-known phenomenon for this silicon surface, and is comparable with plenty of the references in the community (Buehler and Boland, 2000; Ohira et al., 2000; Jung et al., 2001; Cicero et al., 2004).

caption.p: Captured snapshot of the 2×1 reconstruction on the Si(010) surface.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions and prospects
sec.p: In this study, we developed a program for large-scale MD simulation on crystalline silicon and its surface reconstruction, which is of general significance to the simulation of other prominent chemical and physical phenomena of crystalline silicon. Using all 7168 GPUs on Tianhe1A, the simulation of crystalline silicon using the Tersoff potential reaches 1.87 Pflops in SP. Around 80% of instruction throughput and memory throughput can be employed on a single GPU. The simulation reproduces the microscopic behaviors of about 110 billion atoms. Furthermore, by coupling 86,016 CPU cores on Tianhe1A, we achieved a sustainable performance of 1.17 Pflops in SP plus 92.1 Tflops in DP for the simulation of surface reconstruction involving 111 billion atoms and approaching the millimeter scale in one dimension. More importantly, the algorithms developed in the simulations are generalized, transferable, and scalable, and can be used in the study of solid covalent material, nano-/micro-fluidics devices, silane pyrolysis, the silicon deposition process, and so on. The realization of the large-scale simulation at the meso scale provides an opportunity to be coupled with the larger scale directly to achieve trans-scale simulation from atoms to reactors, which will be of ground-breaking significance to a wide range of industries and disciplines.

It is expected that the performance of the simulations can be further improved slightly by combining statistical or control operations to the updating kernel. However, the major performance elevation of the coupled algorithm may come from the optimization of the communication among CPUs and the load balancing among the threads on the CPUs in one node. Two-dimensional and three-dimensional partitions are also promising, meaning that problems with more complicated geometries can be simulated with higher flexibility and efficiency. Defects, impurity, and irregular grain boundaries can also be taken into account.
